citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During the routine inspection, a female alpaca approximately 13 years old named Wilma was observed to have thickened,
abnormal skin with hair loss on her nose and rear legs. The attending veterinarian (AV) examined the animal on October
14th, 2024. Veterinary records show that the AV prescribed a medication to treat the skin condition and the bottle was
obtained. At the time of inspection on 12/5/24, the bottle of medicine was present and dated 10/25/24, but Wilma and her
companion alpaca, Fred, had not been treated as prescribed by the AV. Failure to ensure the attending veterinarian has
appropriate authority over the veterinary care of the animals can lead to unnecessary stress, discomfort, and suffering of
the animals. Not giving the prescribed medication as directed can lead to further discomfort and worsening of the
condition. Each dealer and exhibitor shall assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the
provisions of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use.
***To be corrected by 5:00pm CT on 12/7/24. ***Note, prior to the exit interview on 12/6/24, the facility representatives
corrected the noncompliance by administering the prescribed medication to both Wilma and Fred.
A complete routine inspection was conducted starting on 12/5/24. This inspection report is limited to the Direct non-
compliances identified during that inspection. An additional inspection report will be delivered with the other issues
identified during this inspection.
This inspection was conducted with the facility representatives on 12/5 and 12/6/24. The exit briefing was conducted on
12/6/24 with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
During the routine inspection, a female alpaca approximately 13 years old named Wilma was observed to have thickened, 
abnormal skin with hair loss on her nose and rear legs. The attending veterinarian (AV) examined the animal on October 
14th, 2024. Veterinary records show that the AV prescribed a medication to treat the skin condition and the bottle was 
obtained. At the time of inspection on 12/5/24, the bottle of medicine was present and dated 10/25/24, but Wilma and her 
companion alpaca, Fred, had not been treated as prescribed by the AV. Failure to ensure the attending veterinarian has 
appropriate authority over the veterinary care of the animals can lead to unnecessary stress, discomfort, and suffering of 
the animals. Not giving the prescribed medication as directed can lead to further discomfort and worsening of the 
condition. Each dealer and exhibitor shall assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the 
provisions of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use. 
 
***To be corrected by 5:00pm CT on 12/7/24. ***Note, prior to the exit interview on 12/6/24, the facility representatives 
corrected the noncompliance by administering the prescribed medication to both Wilma and Fred. 
 
A complete routine inspection was conducted starting on 12/5/24. This inspection report is limited to the Direct non-
compliances identified during that inspection. An additional inspection report will be delivered with the other issues 
identified during this inspection. 
 
This inspection was conducted with the facility representatives on 12/5 and 12/6/24. The exit briefing was conducted on 
12/6/24 with the facility representatives.
